segments.title: Teaser Highlights
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: A montage of key quotes from Boris Cherny regarding the shift in software engineering, 100% AI-written code, and the rapid increase in developer productivity.

segments.title: Introduction
segments.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
segments.summary: Lenny introduces Boris Cherny, Head of Claude Code at Anthropic, and frames the conversation around the massive impact Claude Code has had on the software industry in just one year.

segments.title: Sponsor Messages
segments.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
segments.summary: Promotional segments for DX and Sentry.

segments.title: Why Boris Returned to Anthropic
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris discusses his brief departure to join Cursor and his almost immediate return to Anthropic, driven by a deep alignment with the company's safety mission.

segments.title: The Explosive Adoption of Claude Code
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: The pair discuss the staggering statistics of Claude Code's usage, noting that a significant percentage of all GitHub commits are now generated by the tool.

segments.title: Origin Story and Design Decisions
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris recounts how Claude Code started as a hackathon project and explains the rationale behind choosing a terminal-based interface over a traditional IDE extension.

segments.title: Internal Adoption and Product Growth
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris describes how the tool spread virally within Anthropic, initially catching on with data scientists before becoming an essential tool for engineers.

segments.title: The Shifting Landscape of Engineering
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: A discussion on the rapid pace of change in the industry, the concept of building for future models, and how development workflows are fundamentally altering.

segments.title: Coding 100% with AI
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris states that he no longer writes code by hand and shares how his personal workflow has transitioned entirely to using Claude Code.

segments.title: The Next Frontier: Autonomous Agents
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris predicts the next shift involves AI agents acting as coworkers that can proactively find bugs, manage projects, and handle non-coding tasks.

segments.title: Releasing Early for Safety
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris explains why they released Claude Code as a research preview early on: to gather real-world data necessary for ensuring safety and alignment.

segments.title: Claude Cowork and Latent Demand
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Using the story of building Claude Cowork in 10 days, Boris illustrates the principle of 'latent demand'—building products based on how users are hacking existing tools.

segments.title: Adapting Mental Models
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris discusses the challenge of keeping one's mental models up to date with the rapid improvement of AI capabilities and not 'boxing in' the model.

segments.title: Anthropic's Safety Methodology
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: A deep dive into Anthropic's three layers of safety: mechanistic interpretability, rigorous evaluations in a lab setting, and monitoring behavior in the wild.

segments.title: The Bitter Lesson
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris references Rich Sutton's 'Bitter Lesson' to argue why betting on general, scalable models is a better long-term strategy than building specialized systems.

segments.title: Token Economics and Underfunding
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: The discussion turns to the economics of AI, with Boris advising companies to let engineers use unlimited tokens because it leads to massive productivity gains.

segments.title: Pro Tips for Claude Code
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris shares actionable tips for users: always use the most capable model (Opus), utilize 'Plan Mode' for complex tasks, and run multiple agents in parallel.

segments.title: Job Satisfaction Survey
segments.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
segments.summary: Lenny shares poll results indicating most engineers enjoy their jobs more with AI, though designers are more split; Boris adds that removing tedium is a major factor.

segments.title: Thoughts on Competitors
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris briefly touches on the competitive landscape with tools like Codex, emphasizing that competition drives the industry forward but his focus remains on user needs.

segments.title: Post-AGI Plans
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris shares a personal anecdote about living in rural Japan and his plan to return to making miso in a post-AGI world.

segments.title: Lightning Round: Books
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris recommends 'Functional Programming in Scala' for technical depth and sci-fi novels 'Accelerando' and 'The Wandering Earth' for perspective on the future.

segments.title: Lightning Round: Products & Closing
segments.speaker: Boris Cherny
segments.summary: Boris highlights Claude Cowork and the 'Acquired' podcast as his favorite recent products, followed by closing remarks on where to find him online.
